39377800.review:
Evil Genius is now over 13 years old and yet it still retains a huge amount of playability and indeed replayability. I would happily recommend anyone give it a try as long as they arent looking for a quick fix, short attention span game.

If you ever dreamed of being a typical 80's arch villain, if you loved the cheesiness of bond or the Austin Powers films that lampooned the genre then you will likely adore the game.

The game has cheese, strategy, base building, comedy and fun in bundles. The only downside is the absolute grind that generating cash requires. If that bothers you then the simple workaround is to cheat and spawn extra cash so you can focus on the fun that is trap designs and progression. 

Rebellion could do far worse than reinvent this game with Kingsman style themes and retain the same gameplay and progressions but much higher gfx resolutions etc.

The big worry is they start to mess around with the gameplay or 'modernise; things in a Ubisoft kind of way and completely screw it up with some form of badly thought through multiplayer system.

39285365.review: This game, though older, is insanely fun. It can be addicting at times with hillarious ways to defeat the super agents. I recommend this game to just about anyone, especially fans of Strategy games!

It also is very intence,the nail bitting tention when you doing a mission if is stealing uberloot or kidnapping a spinmaster. I have played 10hrs this week and 35hrs complete I have never for a second not wanted to play this game.

39016390.review:
This is one of my favorite games and I was happy to see it come to steam. I still have the cd-rom package from '04, but the disc got destroyed :(

You get to pick an Austin Powers -esque persona and play as an evil genius and try to fulfill your doomsday mission. All of the character sprites or minions/henchmen are interesting to watch, with a unique art style, and there are plenty of fun interactions with base objects to look for. The gameplay consists of building a mountain dungeon, sending your henchmen to the board-game style overworld, and having they steal plans/art/machines to further your ambitions. Some of the art you steal is returned to your base for your henchmen to admire (for a loyalty bonus), and the nations of the world send their agents to retrieve them. Your notoriety increases as you steal more, and the agents become more gooder and tougher and more frequent. Eventually you steal all of the items necessary to complete your doomsday object, and you win!

There are some hurdles along the way:
-You need to dispose of dead bodies.
-Tourists come to the island to... tour. And then they freak out when they see dead bodies or guns.
-You need to train your workers into different careers paths: soldiers, scientists, or social people. Scientists research new items for your base (traps or security features or rec room items), social minions are better suited for non lethal diversion of enemies. Soldiers more effetively arm themselves.
-Super-agents are sent to kill your evil genius, and they each have a unique scenario to defeat them. They will judo-chop your minions all day long if you try to get rid of them like other enemies.

I am very excited for the sequel announced this year. Sierra games was a good publisher.


Likes:
-Base building. There is a ton of freedom to build however you like. Of course, the game doesn't really provide you with much help either. The starting build area is small, but your options improve in the future. I like using the console to enable debug mode to allow more creative building. Do this at your own risk, you can bork your save.

-Traps. They're buggy, but it's fun to set up a room to release bees on unsuspecting investigators. You have to tie a trap with a sensor, and the sensors occupy space, which can limit some designs. Sadly, some agents are too smart and they either won't fall for tripping the trap sensor, or they start attacking and causing the traps to explode. Whomp-whomp.

-Soundtrack. Omg. Just run the OST on Youtube when you're bored at work.

-Modding. The games files are a library of notepad-editable xmls. You can tweak the properties of anything or even define new base items to build. You can go further and add textures to create your own characters. 


Unlikes:
-Controls. Your base consists of you (the evil genius, 1 life), your elite henchmen (limited #, 3 lives), and your minions (unlimited # to hire, 1 life). The minions are assigned to tasks in the background and you cannot re-order a minion to a building task (I.e. if they're right next to a box that need to be moved). Your henchmen can be told to move anywhere and kill anyone and they will, but they don't build. And your evil genius can be told to move anywhere; but, he can't attack, can't build, and his only plus if he produces a passive AoE bonus to your minions (loyalty +, perception +).
 
-Tutorials. Yeah, they suck. The interface for the help videos is also trashy. There's not much in the game that's difficult conceptually, but there are some issues with building that may not be intuitive. I.e. you cannot destroy a room that is the only access path to a deeper room.

-Money. The method for generating cash is by sending henchmen to the world map, in an overworld boardgame-styled menu. Here, any henchmen set to "steal" will produce X amount of dollars per minute. The game with place enemy agents in the region, and there are behind-the-scene dice rolls to kill your henchmen. I don't have much for suggestions in replacing this; but I've always found the # of henchmen required to be on the overworld stealing money at the rate I want to spend it was absurd. There are cheat codes to add $.

-Population cap. I'm not a fan of these, and they're easily editable with the .ini config file, but your pop cap is 100 henchmen. I usually set this to 500. If you need to send 40 of them to the overworld to generate money, it limits your base functionality. There is a slider in your base menu that controls the rate at which you hire new lv 1 henchmen, which can be changed from 1 / min to 1 / sec (w/ a hefty cash penalty).

38906906.review:
Ever felt like playing the bond villian. This game personifies that perfectly, all the tropes and styles. Nameless grunts to carry out your commands and specilized henchmen who can completly change the outcome.

Resource income can be a little slow at time and costly in manpower, but after a slowish start the game really opens up into an amazing build your own evil lair.

With multiple endings depending on your choice of doomsday device, as well as how you deal with the Super agents that come to stop you, this game is a lovely escape to the dark side

38606548.review:
Evil Genius is fantastic. Well deserved reputation as a cult classic. I had nostalgia for Dungeon Keeper 2, but Evil Genius uses the formula and surpasses it quite a bit. For one thing EG is more recent, so it runs well on newer systems. There is a patch and a fix to make it widescreen you should use. But the funny thing is, normally letterbox makes me bounce off a game, but EG is so engrossing I didn't even notice for hours! 

It has a cute, cartoony art style that has helped the graphics age gracefully. The spy theme is novel for this type of game. There is a lot of quirky personality and attention to detail. The orchestral score is great. It has a lengthy campaign. If you don't want to grind then just use an infinite money cheat. Still a blast and a nice challenge. 

I'm glad base builders are gaining more notoriety, pardon the pun. And EG is one of the best ever. I'm happy they're making a proper sequel and I'll be right in line to play it!

37925398.review:
If you like building an empire and enjoy corny humour then this game is for you. A fun take on the dungeon keeper style.

Some things to keep in mind though: This game is glitchy, this game can be frustrating and this game can be slow. If you like fast-paced busy gameplay I wouldn't recommend. Also, get a faq or walkthrough going while playing. Seriously. A lot of the game mechanics are unexplained, glitchy or extremely (and tediously) trial and error.

All this to say, this is game is stll fun and unique if you have some patience. 

4/5 Burly Henchmen.

Mir als James Bond fan hat es auf jeden fall spaß gemacht durchzuspielen. Es hat halt diesen Superagenten charm, auch wenn man auf der bösen Seite steht. 37846830.review:
I've restarted this game several times - you pick one of three Evil Genuis persona (who's perks might be broken if they were never patched) and build a base where you train your minions - they defend your base and run missions on the world map - as you gain infamy your base is attacked by stronger soldiers and eventually Secret Agents (007-like characters) to try and assassinate you.

however, building your base on an island also means that nosey tourists might come along and you also need to keep them out of your base and away from your traps - lest you attract unwanted attention.

inside your base you need to build hallways and training centers and freezers for storing the corpese of all the soldiers your minions kill. - you can rig up traps that can combo with other traps (a wall spring that pushes someone back into a fire pit) which can be entertaining unto itself trying to get combos to work

Evil Genius is one of those games that you sit down at and play for hours at a time and lose track of the clock - but it's not something so obsessive that it's the only game you'll ever play.

Best game ever? no.
Am I glad I played it? sure :P
